user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init:
```c
int32 OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init(osal_objtype_t idtype)
{
    int                     ret;
    int32                   return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    pthread_mutexattr_t     mutex_attr;
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];
    if (impl == NULL)
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    do
    {
        /*
         * initialize the pthread mutex attribute structure with default values
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /*
         * Allow the mutex to use priority inheritance
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /*
         * Use normal (faster/non-recursive) mutex implementation
         * There should not be any instances of OSAL locking its own table more than once.
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_settype(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_MUTEX_NORMAL);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_settype failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        ret = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mutex, &mutex_attr);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutex_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /* create a condition variable with default attributes.
         * This will be broadcast every time the object table changes */
        ret = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cond, NULL);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_cond_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }
    } while (0);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init:

    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED]   = NULL,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK]     = &OS_global_task_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE]    = &OS_queue_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM] = &OS_count_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM]   = &OS_bin_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX]    = &OS_mutex_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM]   = &OS_stream_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB]   = &OS_timecb_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE]   = &OS_module_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS]  = &OS_filesys_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE]  = &OS_console_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR]  = &OS_condvar_lock,
}
...

{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not mark other fragments because they appear to use standard ISO C constructs or POSIX library APIs rather than compiler language extensions. The function body uses standard C control flow, declarations, and POSIX pthread APIs (pthread_mutexattr_init, pthread_mutex_init, pthread_cond_init) which are library/OS APIs rather than language extensions. The typedefs, pointer/const usage, do { ... } while (0) pattern, and the use of errno-style return checking and strerror are all standard C or POSIX usage and not compiler language extensions. The two reported fragments are those most commonly implemented as compiler-specific extensions in some toolchains: variadic macro syntax and index-designated initializers in the array initializer. Other code does not contain additional constructs that are typical compiler language extensions (such as GCC attributes, inline assembly, statement expressions, typeof, zero-length arrays, range designators, or other compiler-specific keywords).
